title: 113_s2558
content: The "Colonias Improvement Act of 2014" may be cited as the short title of this Act. It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Colonias Improvement Act of 2014" defines key terms such as Administrator and covered programs, including water and waste facility loans, wastewater assistance, drinking water assistance, housing assistance, and community development block grant assistance. The "Colonias Improvement Act of 2014" includes assistance programs for colonias such as water and waste facility loans, wastewater assistance, drinking water assistance, housing assistance, and community development block grant assistance. Other programs from EPA, HUD, or USDA that specifically include assistance for colonias are also covered. The "Colonias Improvement Act of 2014" includes various assistance programs for colonias, such as water and waste facility loans, wastewater assistance, drinking water assistance, housing assistance, and community development block grant assistance. Other programs from EPA, HUD, or USDA that specifically include assistance for colonias are also covered. Additionally, there is a revised definition in the act. The "Colonias Improvement Act of 2014" mandates a revised definition of the term "colonia" to be issued within 180 days. The definition must be consistent across all covered programs and limited to communities within 75 miles of the US-Mexico border or those that have received funding before the Act's enactment. The "Colonias Improvement Act of 2014" requires a revised definition of "colonia" to be issued within 180 days. The definition must align with all covered programs, preserve community characteristics, and determine applicant eligibility. The Administrator may grant exemptions, and the final rule must take effect within a year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. WEBPAGE. The Administrator, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Secretary of Agriculture will create a webpage as a central hub for information on covered programs, with links to state-specific details and local contacts. SEC. 5. WORKING GROUP. The Administrator will establish a working group with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and the Secretary of Agriculture to review, record information, hold public hearings, and make recommendations to Congress for improvements to covered programs. A report with the review results must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The report to Congress will include the review results, information summary, recommendations, transportation planning and health considerations, unmet needs survey, key indicators for community living standards, success metrics for programs, and any other relevant information as determined by the Administrator. SEC. 6. CULTURAL SENSITIVITY. The Administrator and those involved in covered programs must be culturally sensitive and work with local organizations in communities served by the programs.
